content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Issues have been fixed. Nice!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I approve of this problem because it is creative and I figure it works alright in all 3 modes.

You have duplicate validators: "The basics 2" and "The basics 3"
Also perhaps add one more test case and validator for "NOT A TRIPLE"
Great idea and clash!
g

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: The idea is interesting but I reject this puzzle so that you can work on it more . Here are some comments:
- your stub generator should include a "write" line
- in the stub generator I would personnaly read 3 ints rather than a string
- your code works for the tests and validators, but it would not work for n=11 or any multiple of a prime that is >10, And I think that there should be tests cases and validators for those situations
- This problem becomes very easy if you know that python has a gcd function (greatest common divider) but that is probably ok for clash of code
- In the statement 2nd paragraph, I would replace "will be" by "is"
- From your input description it looks like a, b and c are separated by a comma and in parentheses, but they are not
- In the output you should also specify that the triple must be space separated
g
I made som changes to the clash. The goal is now more clear and I haveI have elaborated on the constraits description. Hope it helps ^^
I think this has merit but certainly needs some work. I will approve this if you fix the issues listed.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: This looks like a nice clash but : 
1.) maybe more testcases and 1 or 2 edge cases (i.e with 0s)
2.) put markup in your statement
3.) maybe reformat the definition for core triple (i.e The core triple is a Pythagorean triple (a, b, c) where a,b, and c are all integers and coprime amongst them)
and eventually explain coprime

Your solution doesn't match your constraint for n. You try to divide by all numbers until 99, 100 in the last validator is possible after dividing by 2, 5 and 10. With 303, 404 and 505 you won't return 3, 4 and 5.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Super ambiguous,
The example of "The basics 2 " has a,b,c in the bad order.
Which is not mentioned anywhere in the statement.
Your critique is right, I changed it so a b c always is in order. I think that helps for the puzzle. Thanks for the feedback ^^
I'm new to making these. Thank you for your feedback. What would the constraint be? I can change my solutioncode if that's what you meant. ^^

Hi! I appreciate the feedback. I'm new to making these, so it helps:) I liked the idea of using coprimes the explain what I meant by core triple, so I'll be sure to change that. 

What do you mean by markup? I'm not familiar with that term.

And lastly. Wouldt
Thank you crispypear. Means a lot! ^^

Thank you for spending time writing this feedback. It was very helpfull! I how now made changes to the problem and I think it works much better. I added some additional tests for big primes and made the solution work for any input. I liked the idea of separating the input to three different integers instead of a string. Again thank you! ^^

Nice corrections ! For the stub generator you could have used "read a:int b:int c:int" all on the same line, but that works also on different lines. For the write line, I would add "or NOT A TRIPLE" so that we don't have to type that string, but it's just personnal.

One more thing :
The contribution guidelines states that "- Each validator should check the same case as the corresponding test" which they are not. You should keep the test and corresponding validator similar yet different.
Thank you. I changed the inputs to the thing you recommended. It looked better indeed. And I think I changed it so that Test and validator matched better

Ok I'm being picky now, but it bugs me a little that the first test case is so trivial. As the first test case is the only one shown (for the others, we have to print the input to see it), I think it should help debug the code. So it should be simple yet not trivial. For example 6 8 10. 

Also the "more numbers" test should require to divide by more than just one prime factor to reflect the validator.
Done
No problemo, Andret0701! ^^
*Wouldn't more edgcases make it too hard for clash of code? I'll try it out. Thanks ^^

markup : press the ? next to "Statement" whilst editing, it will tell you how to add styling to your statement.

edge cases : it might be a little annoying indeed but I don't think it'd be too difficult to deal with.

I think that the constraint for n doesn't need to be modified (for a, b and c you could precise bounds like 0 and 2^16). It was indeed to notify that your solution code doesn't cover all the possibilities.
